fields.description: This slang can mean something is dangerous or amazing depending on the context. This slang is heavily influenced by the context.
This slang means someone or something is annoying or troublesome.
This slang means 'wait a bit' or 'hold on.' The polite way is '少々お待ちください。 (しょうしょうおまちください。)'
This slang is used to say 'to be honest' or 'to speak frankly.' It’s the same as the polite version.
This slang can be used to describe something awful or extreme. There’s no polite equivalent.
This slang is used when something is funny. The polite way to say it is 'とても興味深いです。 (とてもきょうみぶかいです。)'
This is an informal way to ask 'How are you?' in Japanese.

This is a shorter form of ごめんなさい (I’m sorry). You can use this slang among friends. Your boss can use this, but you can't use when you'll talk with the boss. Really, if you want to apologize properly, you should say ごめんなさい or すみません. The most sincerely and often used version is 申し訳ございません or 申し訳ないです. The highest version is 誠に申し訳ございませんでした. This version is used in press conference.
This term is a very informal way to refer to 'them' in Japanese.
This phrase is used when taking a photo, similar to saying 'Cheese!' in English.
This slang is used in mainly work or discussion.

fields.formal_version: はじめまして。よろしくお願いします。
fields.description: This is used in a first meeting to show your politeness and familiarity. The important point is that you should deliver your attitude to the other one with body language.
いくつ is used to count something. When you face the other one and say いくつ, it means you're asking about the other's age. Generally speaking, Japanese don't often ask the age but they care it seriously.
めっちゃ is originally from Kansai destrict. Now mainly younger people use that everywhere in Japan.

Probably わからん is from Kansai destrict, but this doesn't have strong nuance that this word from Kansai. This is a little rough, you can't use in a formal meeting or official conference. Of course you can't use when you talk with your boss.

fields.formal_version: 何かあればよろしくお願いします
fields.description: This phrase is used at the end of a meeting to express a desire to stay connected and meet again in the future.
Among friends, it's okay to use this phrase casually. Otherwise, a bossy superior might use this with a team member.

fields.formal_version: すみません、もう一度お願いします。
fields.description: Using なんて alone can sound a bit rough. Adding polite cushion words softens the tone.

fields.formal_version: ちなみに、お値段はどれくらいになるでしょうか？
fields.description: When talking to shop staff, you should say すみません、いくらでしょうか？ This phrase is casual and should be used only with friends, not with people you're meeting for the first time.
The tone is crucial. Use a soft tone with this phrase if you want to avoid sounding confrontational.

fields.formal_version: さわやかで人当たりがいいですね
fields.description: さわやか is a very Japanese concept, referring to a man who is cool, friendly, youthful, and reliable—essentially a decent, well-rounded person

fields.formal_version: あの人とは相性が悪いです
fields.description: The meaning depends on the context. It can be used jokingly or seriously, depending on the situation.
